original_title: Sri Lanka plans to make Colombo and Trinco ports hubs for green hydrogen: President
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka will seek investments to make Colombo and Trincomalee ports hubs for the export of green hydrogen and green ammonia made with renewable energy, President Ranil Wickremesinghe said.

Sri Lanka had plans to make 70 percent of electricity renewable energy by 2030. The North and East region would be a key source of renewable energy, which would be developed in partnership with India.

“One of the key objectives of the Northern and Eastern development plans is to harness the regions renewable energy potential through the production of green hydrogen and green ammonia using innovative technology,” President Ranil Wickremesinghe told parliament.
Green hydrogen is a key future ship fuels that could replace fossil bunkers. Green ammonia is another fuel made from green hydrogen by adding nitrogen separated from the air with renewable energy.
“This strategy aims to attract investments and could transform the port of Colombo as hubs for the export of green hydrogen,” President Wickremesinghe said.
A memorandum of understanding had been signed with India to develop solar and wind power.
Pooneryn in the North will be developed as the main town in renewable energy production. India’s Adani has come forward as one of the investors, he said. (Colombo/Aug10/2023)
